explanation:
For checking MISRA C string.h bounds violations you must inspect any callees or data/type definitions that (a) move or copy memory, or (b) compute sizes/offsets used as lengths/addresses. Brief explanations for each required symbol:

- lfs_bd_read: performs block reads into buffers. Could call memcpy/memmove or otherwise copy into provided buffers; need prototype and implementation to verify it limits reads to buffer lengths passed (prevents overwrites).
- lfs_bd_crc: reads data and computes CRCs; may internally read blocks or copy data (calls lfs_bd_read). Verify any internal buffer copies and length parameters used.
- lfs_bd_prog: programs (writes) data to storage; may copy from caller buffers or use memcpy before programming. Verify it respects the provided size and does not read/write beyond supplied buffers.
- lfs_bd_sync: synchronizes caches/flushes; may invoke buffer operations that copy or zero memory (could use memset/memcpy). Must inspect for safe bounds use.
- lfs_bd_flush: called by bd_prog/sync; implementation may move cache contents (memcpy/memset); need to check its buffer handling.
- lfs_cache_drop: manages cache buffers; may zero or move memory ranges—inspect for correct bounds handling.
- lfs_dir_commitattr: called from the target to write an FCRC tag; it calls lfs_dir_commitprog and lfs_bd_read. Its implementation may copy attribute payloads—must inspect for safe uses of string.h functions.
- lfs_dir_commitprog: lower-level commit write helper called by commitattr/target; likely handles payload buffers and lengths—must inspect for any memcpy/memset/memcmp uses and ensure lengths are correct.
- lfs_fcrc_tole32: converts struct lfs_fcrc endianness; may use memcpy or field-wise conversion; check for safe accesses of the struct passed.
- lfs_tole32 / lfs_tobe32: byte-order helpers used to pack/unpack tags and crc fields; implementations may use pointer casting or memcpy—inspect to ensure no out-of-bounds accesses.
- lfs_crc: CRC accumulator called with pointers and sizes; may read bytes from provided pointers—need its prototype/behavior to ensure it only reads declared sizes.
- lfs_min, lfs_alignup, lfs_aligndown, lfs_max: used extensively to compute offsets/lengths (end, noff, boundaries). Their semantics are required to ensure the computed sizes passed to read/prog calls do not underflow/overflow and remain within buffer and block bounds.
- lfs_tag_t: tag type (size and representation) is used in size computations (sizeof(lfs_tag_t)) — must know exact size to check pointer/length arithmetic.
- struct lfs_fcrc: layout/size used when creating/writing FCRC (sizeof(struct lfs_fcrc)) — required to validate the length passed to commitattr and any conversions.
- struct lfs_t, struct lfs_commit, struct lfs_config (cfg): the filesystem, commit and config structures contain fields used to compute sizes (cfg->prog_size, cfg->block_size, cfg->cache_size) and buffer/offset/state (commit->off, commit->begin, commit->crc, commit->ptag, pcache/rcache). Need their definitions to verify that offsets/lengths are correct and that pointers passed to lower-level I/O functions reference valid memory ranges.
- lfs_off_t: integer type for offsets; its signedness/width matters for arithmetic and bound checks (prevent negative/overflow behavior when computing noff/end/etc.).
- LFS_ERR_CORRUPT: error code checked after bd_read/bd_crc calls; include to understand control flow and when potentially truncated reads are considered acceptable (the target treats LFS_ERR_CORRUPT specially).

In short: to determine whether any string.h functions (memcpy/memmove/memset/memcmp/etc.) are used out-of-bounds you must inspect the implementations of the block I/O and commit helpers listed above, plus the relevant type/layout and size/offset helpers used by the target to compute lengths and buffer addresses. The symbols above are the minimal set required to trace any internal uses of C standard library string functions and validate the correctness of all length/offset arithmetic performed before such calls.
